Massachusetts Republican Governor Mitt Romney announced Wednesday he will not seek re-election next fall.
His departure is welcome news to Democrats who last saw one of their own as governor when Michael Dukakis left office in 1991.
So far the Republican field is wide open.
But there are two Democrats already running, Attorney General Tom Reilly and civil rights lawyer Deval Patrick.
If elected, Patrick would be only the second black elected governor in US history.
The first was Virginia's Douglas Wilder in 1990.
Born in 1956, Deval Patrick lived in a tiny apartment on Chicago's turbulent South Side.
When he was four, his father left the family to travel as a jazz musician.
The young Patrick immersed himself in his schoolwork and would eventually attend Harvard.
After graduation, Patrick spent a year in Africa, where he (technical difficulties) law school application in the Sudan desert.
For years he argued civil rights cases for the NAACP, and in 1994, President Clinton tapped him to head the Justice Department's civil rights division.
More recently, Patrick has served as vice president and general counsel for two corporate giants, Texaco and Coca-Cola.
Deval Patrick recently told me his decision to run for governor of Massachusetts wasn't political; it was personal.
I've lived here for most of the last 35 years.
I've raised a family here with my wife, and I love this state.
But the state is slipping behind, and I'm persuaded that the same old thing from the same old insiders is not going to help.

I'm trying to bring to bear a range of leadership experience that comes from the highest levels of government, from business, from community work and not-for-profits to bear in trying to address some real challenges that we're facing in real people's lives.
But there are those who are going to believe that an African-American cannot win state office in Massachusetts.
What do you say to that?
Well, there are people who've been saying that African-Americans can't do this or that thing for generations here in America, you know, and I've had that same experience in my life.
People said I couldn't move from the South Side of Chicago to where I was raised to go to Harvard, and I did.
People said, you know, I couldn't be a partner in a downtown law firm.
I became one.
They said someone like me couldn't be a general counsel for two of the largest corporations in the world, and I served in that role for both Texaco and the Coca-Cola Company.
So I'm accustomed to hearing skeptics and ignoring them.
I think they--the important thing here is not what I am but what I bring.
And what I bring is a range of leadership experience, which is unlike anyone else on the Democratic or the Republican side and a commitment to try to get Massachusetts moving forward again.

So many people talk about the idea of the new African-American politician, not necessarily as steeped in the civil rights movement; that they bring a number of other areas and thoughts to bear politically, if you will, in your case, corporate America, legal experience, etc. Do you consider yourself the, quote, ""new African-American politician""?
I'm reluctant to accept any tag under any circumstances, Ed, but I take the point.
I mean, I have, as you know, had my own professional experience in civil rights, both as a private attorney and as head of the civil rights division in the Clinton administration.
And I certainly acknowledge and credit and am grateful for the incredible contributions of people in that struggle before me who made possible the kinds of opportunities I've had.
But I bring some other things to the table, as you said, including experience in business, experience in community work and not-for-profits as well.
And I know from those experiences that sometimes the best solutions come from partnership between government and those different worlds.
Let me ask you this.
You talked about your experience in the civil rights division of the Justice Department.

We have been on this program over the course of the last couple of weeks talking about what many inside that division are now calling the decimation of that division; that it has now become too political, that assignments are now doled out based on political sensibilities and the like.

I'm just devastated by what's happening in the civil rights division today.
I mean, the division is out of the business of civil rights.
And I'm not talking about just a change in emphasis.
I'm talking about a decline in impact.

When I was there in the Clinton administration, the political appointees and the career professionals worked in partnership in trying to bring an aggressive and robust enforcement agenda across the range of civil rights laws for which the division was responsible.
And we had some wonderful accomplishments.
We had a fair lending enforcement program, which the banking industry itself credits for a record increase in homeownership among the black and brown people in this country.

We responded to a rash of attacks on black churches and synagogues in the South with what was then the largest criminal investigation in American history until 9/11 and broke the back of that epidemic of violence.
We were involved in responses to abortion clinic attacks.
This is the business of the civil rights division, and that business isn't being done today.
And it's not being done because of political lack of interest, frankly, by the current administration.
And it's just a darn shame.
